O	Controlling birth rates allows families to raise the future earnings power of the next generation.	Having children produces a quality-quantity trade-off: parents need to decide how many children to have and how much to invest in the future of each child [ref].	1_5
E	Controlling birth rates allows families to raise the future earnings power of the next generation.	The increasing marginal cost of quality (child outcome) with respect to quantity (number of children) creates a trade-off between quantity and quality [ref].	1_5
E	Controlling birth rates allows families to raise the future earnings power of the next generation.	The quantity-quality trade-off means that policies that raise benefits of investing in child quality will generate higher levels of human capital, and policies that lower the costs of having children may have unintended adverse consequences on long-run economic growth.	1_5
E	Controlling birth rates allows families to raise the future earnings power of the next generation.	When deciding how many children, parents are influenced by their income level, perceived return to human capital investment, and cultural norms related to gender equality.	1_5

While the orthogonality thesis follows logically from even the weakest sort of philosophical is-ought distinction, Stuart Armstrong argues that even if there somehow exist moral facts that are provable by any rational agent, the orthogonality thesis still holds: it would still be possible to create a non-philosophical optimizing machine capable of making decisions to strive towards some narrow goal, but that has no incentive to discover any moral facts that would get in the way of goal completion [ref].	5_3

O	All animal liberationists believe that the individual interests of non-human animals deserve recognition and protection, but the movement can be split into two broad camps.	Animal rights movement	16_4
O	All animal liberationists believe that the individual interests of non-human animals deserve recognition and protection, but the movement can be split into two broad camps.	The animal rights movement, sometimes called the animal liberation movement, animal personhood, or animal advocacy movement, is a social movement which seeks an end to the rigid moral and legal distinction drawn between human and non-human animals, an end to the status of animals as property, and an end to their use in the research, food, clothing, and entertainment industries.	16_4
O	All animal liberationists believe that the individual interests of non-human animals deserve recognition and protection, but the movement can be split into two broad camps.	Terms and factions	16_4

E	All animal liberationists believe that the individual interests of non-human animals deserve recognition and protection, but the movement can be split into two broad camps.	Animal rights advocates, or rights liberationists, believe that these basic interests confer moral rights of some kind on the animals, and/or ought to confer legal rights on them;[1] see, for example, the work of Tom Regan.	16_4
E	All animal liberationists believe that the individual interests of non-human animals deserve recognition and protection, but the movement can be split into two broad camps.	Utilitarian liberationists, on the other hand, do not believe that animals possess moral rights, but argue, on utilitarian grounds — utilitarianism in its simplest form advocating that we base moral decisions on the greatest happiness of the greatest number — that, because animals have the ability to suffer, their suffering must be taken into account in any moral philosophy.	16_4
E	All animal liberationists believe that the individual interests of non-human animals deserve recognition and protection, but the movement can be split into two broad camps.	To exclude animals from that consideration, they argue, is a form of discrimination that they call speciesism; see, for example, the work of Peter Singer [ref].	16_4

O	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	Leading researchers gathered to contribute findings on firms, trade, and development at Stanford University in early November 2016.	18_4
O	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	The conference covered such as the measurement of productivity, the effects of integrating suppliers in fishmeal manufacturing, and the potential for increased domestic demand for drugs to increase their export potential.	18_4
O	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	Image Credit: Jean Rebiffé	18_4
O	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	A recurring topic was rural-to-urban migration and its links to changing labour markets.	18_4
O	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	The movement of labour from rural to urban areas has long been an integral part of theories of “structural transformation”: the movement of economic activity among sectors, particularly from agriculture to manufacturing.	18_4
O	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	As people move from agricultural work to higher-productivity jobs in cities, countries can undergo an important transformation that may increase not only workers’ wages but also the country’s economic growth as a whole.	18_4
O	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	However, many questions remain about the effects of such rural-urban migration and how workers can be incentivised to move.	18_4
O	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	If wages are so much higher in cities, as documented by large rural-urban productivity gaps in virtually every country, then why do people still live in rural areas, and what could increase their chances of finding urban jobs?	18_4
O	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	The following three studies presented at the conference explore these rural-urban linkages and present key ideas on the relationship between migration and structural transformation	18_4
O	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	1	18_4
O	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	18_4
E	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	Mushfiq Mobarak presented the effects of rural-urban migration on rural labour markets in Bangladesh in his recent paper with Agha Ali Akram and Shyamal Chowdhury.	18_4
E	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	In particular, they study how seasonal rural-urban migration affects the broader rural economy through a large-scale randomised control trial.	18_4
E	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	By offering to subsidise transportation costs for 5,792 potential seasonal migrants in Bangladesh trying to escape the annual famine season, the authors identify the effect of increasing the number of migrant workers on total migration numbers and income levels in rural villages.	18_4
E	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	The authors randomly vary the proportion of migrating landless agricultural workers across 133 villages in order to generate labour supply shocks of different magnitudes in different villages.	18_4
E	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	They then use this variation to document the general equilibrium changes in wages and prices from significantly scaling up the seasonal migration subsidy project Mobarak piloted a few years ago.	18_4
E	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	Effectively, these changes represent how the project affects villages in their entirety when the project is rolled out on a large scale with high numbers of simultaneous migrations per village.	18_4
E	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	First, the authors find that a higher proportion of migrants leaving rural villages during the famine season means that other people in the village were more likely to migrate as well.	18_4
E	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	This suggests that there are some benefits of coordinated travel, whereby migrants can share the cost of leaving the village temporarily.	18_4
E	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	Second, they find a large increase in the income earned both at the destination and in the original village.	18_4
E	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	For every 10% increase in rural-urban migration, male agricultural wages increase by 2.8%.	18_4
E	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	These findings suggest that interventions to incentivise people to move to cities temporarily to get better paid jobs make sense when the poverty in the rural villages is chronic and seasonal.	18_4
O	Migration begets migration and improves both rural and urban wages	2	18_4

O	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	Urbanisation: Trends, Causes and Effects	18_9

O	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	These changes in population lead to other changes in land use, economic activity and culture.	18_9
O	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	Historically, urbanisation has been associated with significant economic and social transformations.	18_9
O	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	For example, urban living is linked with higher levels of literacy and education, better health, lower fertility and a longer life expectancy, greater access to social services and enhanced opportunities for cultural and political participation (UNDESA, 2014).	18_9
O	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	However, urbanisation also has disadvantages caused by rapid and unplanned urban growth resulting in poor infrastructures such as inadequate housing, water and sanitation, transport and health care services.	18_9
O	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	Rural to urban migration	18_9
O	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	18_9
O	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	The movement of people from one place to another is called migration.	18_9
O	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	Migration is influenced by economic growth and development and by technological change (Marshall et al., 2009) and possibly also by conflict and social disruption.	18_9
O	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	It is driven by pull factors that attract people to urban areas and push factors that drive people away from the countryside.	18_9
E	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	Employment opportunities in cities are one of the main pull factors.	18_9
E	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	Many industries are located in cities and offer opportunities of high urban wages.	18_9
E	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	There are also more educational institutions providing courses and training in a wide range of subjects and skills.	18_9
E	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	People are attracted to an urban lifestyle and the ‘bright lights’ of city life.	18_9
E	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	All of these factors result in both temporary and permanent migration to urban areas.	18_9
E	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	Poor living conditions and the lack of opportunities for paid employment in rural areas are push factors.	18_9
E	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	People are moving away from rural areas because of poor health care and limited educational and economic opportunities as well as environmental changes, droughts, floods, lack of availability of sufficiently productive land, and other pressures on rural livelihoods.	18_9
O	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	Rural to urban migration can be a selective process, as some types of people are more likely to move than others.	18_9
O	In developing countries, urbanisation usually occurs when people move from villages to settle in cities in hope of gaining a better standard of living.	One of the factors involved is gender, because employment opportunities vary greatly with different jobs for men and women.	18_9

O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	First we will look at the many positive impacts of urbanisation before going on to describe some of the challenges created by rapid unplanned urban growth.	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	Thriving towns and cities are an essential element of a prosperous national economy.	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	The gathering of economic and human resources in one place stimulates innovation and development in business, science, technology and industry.	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	Access to education, health, social services and cultural activities is more readily available to people in cities than in villages.	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	In cities, child survival rates are better than in rural areas because of better access to health care (Mulholland et al., 2008).	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	The density of urban populations makes it easier and less costly for the government and utilities to provide essential goods and services (Brockerhoff, 2000).	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	For example, the supply of basic facilities such as fresh water and electricity can be achieved with less effort and less cost per person.	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	Schools, colleges and universities are established in cities to develop human resources.	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	A variety of educational courses are available, offering students a wide choice for their future careers.	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	People of many classes and religions live and work together in cities, which creates better understanding and harmony and helps break down social and cultural barriers.	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	Cities also have advanced communication and transport networks.	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	However, these many benefits of urban life do not apply to all.	18_9

E	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	In Ethiopia, the rate of urban growth often strains the capacity of local and national government to provide urban residents with even the most basic services of housing, water supply, sewerage and solid waste disposal (MWUD, 2008).	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	Housing	18_9
E	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	In developing countries, about a third of urban inhabitants live in impoverished slums and squatter settlements (UN-Habitat, 2012).	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	Slums are urban areas that are heavily populated and have sub-standard housing with very poor living conditions, creating several problems.	18_9
E	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	In Addis Ababa, a report in 2008 found that 80% of the houses in the city were classed as slums due to the physical deterioration of its housing, overcrowding, high density, poor access and lack of infrastructure services	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	Slum areas typically suffer from:	18_9
O	Rapid population increases and unplanned growth create an urban sprawl with negative economic, social, and environmental consequences.	poor housing with small, overcrowded houses built very close together using inadequate materials and with uncertain electricity supply	18_9

O	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	restricted access to water supplies	18_9

O	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	Poverty is one of the most critical issues facing urban areas.	18_9
O	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	Urban poverty degrades both the physical and social environment.	18_9
O	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	This then makes it more difficult for people to escape from poverty and they fall victim to the ‘vicious cycle’ that you read about in Study Session 2.	18_9
O	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	Water supply and sanitation	18_9
E	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	18_9
E	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	The increased demand for water from the growing population can place added stress on already stretched resources.	18_9
E	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	In and around cities, water is commonly in short supply and subject to increasing competition by different users.	18_9
E	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	Urban growth leads to increasing demand for water for industrial and domestic use, which conflicts with agricultural demands.	18_9
E	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	It is especially difficult to provide water and sanitation services to deprived areas and the poorest people.	18_9
E	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	Many people in these areas live without access to safe drinking water and proper sanitation.	18_9
E	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	Even where adequate water supplies are available, sanitation and wastewater disposal are often inadequate or missing.	18_9
E	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	Pit latrines and septic tanks are the usual methods for human waste disposal but they have limited capacity and are not always adequate to cope with the quantity of waste produced by many people living close together.	18_9
E	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	Overflowing latrines and septic tanks contaminate surface water and create a serious health risk.	18_9
O	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges. O	The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban and slum areas presents critical challenges.	In Africa and Asia most of the urban centres have no sewers at all, which affects rich and poor alike.	18_9

O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	Urbanisation can have both positive and negative effects on health.	18_9
O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	The main benefits are associated with easier access to hospitals, clinics and health services in general.	18_9
O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	If you live close to these services you can reach a doctor in minutes rather than hours or days, so this improves emergency care and general health.	18_9
O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	There are also benefits from easier access to sources of information such as radio and television which may be used to communicate information about health to the general public.	18_9
O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	For example, women living in towns and cities are more likely to be informed about family planning, which results in reduction in family size and less frequent childbirth, with consequent benefits to general health.	18_9
O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	However, urban life can also damage your health.	18_9
O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	Poor environment, housing and living conditions are the main reasons for poor health in urban areas.	18_9
O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	Contamination of water sources can cause epidemics of waterborne disease.	18_9
O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	Close proximity to other people can make the spread of many types of infectious disease more likely.	18_9
O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	The polluted air can also cause respiratory disease and contribute to premature deaths among more vulnerable sections of the population such as older people and children.	18_9
O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	Food	18_9

E	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	As people migrate to the cities, they tend to use purchased food instead of their own crops and this makes them more vulnerable to changes in food prices.	18_9
E	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	As the population grows and the demand for water and land increases, it becomes difficult to increase food production in a sustainable way.	18_9
E	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	The increase in urban demand, combined with a loss of agricultural land, means more pressure on rural people to produce food for the growing number of urban people.	18_9
E	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	Furthermore, pollution from urban areas can disrupt food supply.	18_9
O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	For example, fisheries are often damaged by urban domestic wastes and liquid effluents from city-based industries.	18_9
O	Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.	(Effluent is another word for wastewater that flows out from a source.)	18_9

O	According to The 2007 Pew Global Attitudes Project, Throughout Western Europe and much of the Americas, there is widespread tolerance towards homosexuality. O	Internet gambling will drive network development;	First, Internet technology renders prohibitionfutile.	45_10

O	Internet gambling will drive network development;	Second, as an international network, theInternet offers an instant detour around merely domesticprohibitions.	45_10
O	Internet gambling will drive network development;	Principles of national sovereignty willprevent the U.S. from forcing other countries to enforce a ban onInternet gambling, and it takes only one safe harbor abroad toensure that U.S. citizens can gamble over the Internet.	45_10
O	Internet gambling will drive network development;	Third, consumer demand for Internet gamblingand the states' demand for tax revenue will create enormouspolitical pressure for legalization.	45_10

O	Because everyone gets the same test and the same grading system, standardized tests are often perceived as being fairer than non-standardized test.	Standardized test	62_4
O	Because everyone gets the same test and the same grading system, standardized tests are often perceived as being fairer than non-standardized test.	A standardized test is a test that is administered and scored in a consistent, or standard, manner.	62_4
O	Because everyone gets the same test and the same grading system, standardized tests are often perceived as being fairer than non-standardized test.	Standardized tests are designed in such a way that the questions, conditions for administering, scoring procedures, and interpretations are consistent[1] and are administered and scored in a predetermined, standard manner [ref].	62_4
O	Because everyone gets the same test and the same grading system, standardized tests are often perceived as being fairer than non-standardized test.	Any test in which the same test is given in the same manner to all test takers, and graded in the same manner for everyone, is a standardized test.	62_4
O	Because everyone gets the same test and the same grading system, standardized tests are often perceived as being fairer than non-standardized test.	Standardized tests do not need to be high-stakes tests, time-limited tests, or multiple-choice tests.	62_4
O	Because everyone gets the same test and the same grading system, standardized tests are often perceived as being fairer than non-standardized test.	The questions can be simple or complex.	62_4
O	Because everyone gets the same test and the same grading system, standardized tests are often perceived as being fairer than non-standardized test.	The subject matter among school-age students is frequently academic skills, but a standardized test can be given on nearly any topic, including driving tests, creativity, personality, professional ethics, or other attributes.	62_4
O	Because everyone gets the same test and the same grading system, standardized tests are often perceived as being fairer than non-standardized test.	The opposite of standardized testing is non-standardized testing, in which either significantly different tests are given to different test takers, or the same test is assigned under significantly different conditions (e.g., one group is permitted far less time to complete the test than the next group) or evaluated differently (e.g., the same answer is counted right for one student, but wrong for another student).	62_4
O	Because everyone gets the same test and the same grading system, standardized tests are often perceived as being fairer than non-standardized test.	Most everyday quizzes and tests taken by students typically meet the definition of a standardized test: everyone in the class takes the same test, at the same time, under the same circumstances, and all of the students are graded by their teacher in the same way.	62_4
O	Because everyone gets the same test and the same grading system, standardized tests are often perceived as being fairer than non-standardized test.	However, the term standardized test is most commonly used to refer to tests that are given to larger groups, such as a test taken by all adults who wish to acquire a license to have a particular kind of job, or by all students of a certain age.	62_4

Such tests are often thought of as fairer and more objective than a system in which some students get an easier test and others get a more difficult test.	62_4

Standardized tests are designed in such a way that the questions, conditions for administering, scoring procedures, and interpretations are consistent[1] and are administered and scored in a predetermined, standard manner [ref].	62_4
O	Such tests are often thought of as fairer and more objective than a system in which some students get an easier test and others get a more difficult test.	Any test in which the same test is given in the same manner to all test takers, and graded in the same manner for everyone, is a standardized test.	62_4
O	Such tests are often thought of as fairer and more objective than a system in which some students get an easier test and others get a more difficult test.	Standardized tests do not need to be high-stakes tests, time-limited tests, or multiple-choice tests.	62_4
O	Such tests are often thought of as fairer and more objective than a system in which some students get an easier test and others get a more difficult test.	The questions can be simple or complex.	62_4
O	Such tests are often thought of as fairer and more objective than a system in which some students get an easier test and others get a more difficult test.	The subject matter among school-age students is frequently academic skills, but a standardized test can be given on nearly any topic, including driving tests, creativity, personality, professional ethics, or other attributes.	62_4
O	Such tests are often thought of as fairer and more objective than a system in which some students get an easier test and others get a more difficult test.	The opposite of standardized testing is non-standardized testing, in which either significantly different tests are given to different test takers, or the same test is assigned under significantly different conditions (e.g., one group is permitted far less time to complete the test than the next group) or evaluated differently (e.g., the same answer is counted right for one student, but wrong for another student).	62_4
O	Such tests are often thought of as fairer and more objective than a system in which some students get an easier test and others get a more difficult test.	Most everyday quizzes and tests taken by students typically meet the definition of a standardized test: everyone in the class takes the same test, at the same time, under the same circumstances, and all of the students are graded by their teacher in the same way.	62_4
O	Such tests are often thought of as fairer and more objective than a system in which some students get an easier test and others get a more difficult test.	However, the term standardized test is most commonly used to refer to tests that are given to larger groups, such as a test taken by all adults who wish to acquire a license to have a particular kind of job, or by all students of a certain age.	62_4

O	A new study from the National Association for College Admission Counseling provides evidence that test-optional policies ― a variety of policies that allow students not to submit scores on standardized tests like the SAT or GRE during the admissions process ― can help colleges improve their diversity without sacrificing academic quality.	Abolish Standardized Testing For College Admissions	62_6
E	A new study from the National Association for College Admission Counseling provides evidence that test-optional policies ― a variety of policies that allow students not to submit scores on standardized tests like the SAT or GRE during the admissions process ― can help colleges improve their diversity without sacrificing academic quality.	A new study from the National Association for College Admission Counseling provides evidence that test-optional policies ― a variety of policies that allow students not to submit scores on standardized tests like the SAT or GRE during the admissions process ― can help colleges improve their diversity without sacrificing academic quality.	62_6
E	A new study from the National Association for College Admission Counseling provides evidence that test-optional policies ― a variety of policies that allow students not to submit scores on standardized tests like the SAT or GRE during the admissions process ― can help colleges improve their diversity without sacrificing academic quality.	The study found that schools that do not require the SAT/ACT saw an increased enrollment of underrepresented students of color relative to comparable institutions that require a test score and that admitted students who did not submit scores were just as likely to graduate as admitted students who did.	62_6
O	A new study from the National Association for College Admission Counseling provides evidence that test-optional policies ― a variety of policies that allow students not to submit scores on standardized tests like the SAT or GRE during the admissions process ― can help colleges improve their diversity without sacrificing academic quality.	The report also found that high school grade point average (GPA) was a better predictor of success in college GPA than test scores for non-submitters.	62_6

E	Juvenile curfews are a violation of young people’s fundamental rights.	Both the U.S. Constitution and the U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child state that freedom of movement and association is an important right.	66_5
E	Juvenile curfews are a violation of young people’s fundamental rights.	Federal courts have also recognized that curfew-imposed restrictions are a violation of First Amendment rights such as free speech and assembly, and therefore have struck down many curfews that fail to give free speech exemptions.	66_5
E	Juvenile curfews are a violation of young people’s fundamental rights.	Along with First Amendment rights, curfews violate fair and equal treatment under the law as well as substantive and procedural due process, making them unconstitutional in other ways as well.	66_5

O	Juvenile curfews are a violation of young people’s fundamental rights.	Curfew violations are a type of status offense, which means they criminalize behavior that is only illegal because the person involved is under eighteen.	66_5
O	Juvenile curfews are a violation of young people’s fundamental rights.	Status offenses unfairly punish young people for activity that is not considered dangerous to society (otherwise it would be illegal for everyone to do it).	66_5

O	vaccines are among the most effective tools available for preventing infectious diseases and their complications and sequelae.	Vaccination was introduced in the United States at the turn of the 19th century.	70_9
O	vaccines are among the most effective tools available for preventing infectious diseases and their complications and sequelae.	The first U.S. law to require smallpox vaccination was passed soon afterward, in 1809 in Massachusetts, to prevent and control frequent smallpox outbreaks that had substantial health and economic consequences.12-14 Subsequently, other states enacted similar legislation.13 Despite the challenges inherent in establishing a reliable and safe vaccine delivery system, vaccination became widely accepted as an effective tool for preventing smallpox through the middle of the 19th century, and the incidence of smallpox declined between 1802 and 1840.15 In the 1850s, “irregular physicians, the advocates of unorthodox medical theories,”16 led challenges to vaccination.	70_9
O	vaccines are among the most effective tools available for preventing infectious diseases and their complications and sequelae. O	High immunization coverage has resulted in drastic declines in vaccine-preventable diseases, particularly in many high- and middle-income countries.	Vaccination was introduced in the United States at the turn of the 19th century.	70_9
O	High immunization coverage has resulted in drastic declines in vaccine-preventable diseases, particularly in many high- and middle-income countries.	The first U.S. law to require smallpox vaccination was passed soon afterward, in 1809 in Massachusetts, to prevent and control frequent smallpox outbreaks that had substantial health and economic consequences.12-14 Subsequently, other states enacted similar legislation.13 Despite the challenges inherent in establishing a reliable and safe vaccine delivery system, vaccination became widely accepted as an effective tool for preventing smallpox through the middle of the 19th century, and the incidence of smallpox declined between 1802 and 1840.15 In the 1850s, “irregular physicians, the advocates of unorthodox medical theories,”16 led challenges to vaccination.	70_9
O	High immunization coverage has resulted in drastic declines in vaccine-preventable diseases, particularly in many high- and middle-income countries.	Vaccine use decreased, and smallpox made a major reappearance in the 1870s.15 Many states passed new vaccination laws, whereas other states started enforcing existing laws.	70_9
O	High immunization coverage has resulted in drastic declines in vaccine-preventable diseases, particularly in many high- and middle-income countries.	Increased enforcement of the laws often resulted in increased opposition to vaccination.	70_9

O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	Vaccines are among the most effective prevention tools available to clinicians.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	However, the success of an immunization program depends on high rates of acceptance and coverage.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	There is evidence of an increase in vaccine refusal in the United States and of geographic clustering of refusals that results in outbreaks.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	Children with exemptions from school immunization requirements (a measure of vaccine refusal) are at increased risk for measles and pertussis and can infect others who are too young to be vaccinated, cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons, or were vaccinated but did not have a sufficient immunologic response.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	Clinicians can play a crucial role in parental decision making.	70_9

Health care providers are cited as the most frequent source of immunization information by parents, including parents of unvaccinated children.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	Although some clinicians have discontinued or have considered discontinuing their provider relationship with patients who refuse vaccines, the American Academy of Pediatrics Committee on Bioethics advises against this and recommends that clinicians address vaccine refusal by respectfully listening to parental concerns and discussing the risks of nonvaccination.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	vaccines are among the most effective tools available for preventing infectious diseases and their complications and sequelae.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	High immunization coverage has resulted in drastic declines in vaccine-preventable diseases, particularly in many high- and middle-income countries.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	A reduction in the incidence of a vaccine-preventable disease often leads to the public perception that the severity of the disease and susceptibility to it have decreased.1 At the same time, public concern about real or perceived adverse events associated with vaccines has increased.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	This heightened level of concern often results in an increase in the number of people refusing vaccines.1,2	70_9
E	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	In the United States, policy interventions, such as immunization requirements for school entry, have contributed to high vaccine coverage and record or near-record lows in the levels of vaccine-preventable diseases.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	Recent parental concerns about perceived vaccine safety issues, such as a purported association between vaccines and autism, though not supported by a credible body of scientific evidence,3-8 have led increasing numbers of parents to refuse or delay vaccination for their children.9,10 The primary measure of vaccine refusal in the United States is the proportion of children who are exempted from school immunization requirements for nonmedical reasons.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person. O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	Several states, including California, Illinois, Indiana, Minnesota, Utah, West Virginia, and Wisconsin, repealed compulsory vaccination laws.15 Many other states retained them.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	In a 1905 landmark case, Jacobson v. Massachusetts, which has since served as the foundation for public health laws, the U.S. Supreme Court endorsed the rights of states to pass and enforce compulsory vaccination laws.17 In 1922, deciding a case filed by a girl excluded from a public school (and later a private school) in San Antonio, Texas, the Supreme Court found school immunization requirements to be constitutional.18 Since then, courts have been generally supportive of the states' power to enact and implement immunization requirements.	70_9
O	Herd immunity, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases, thereby benefiting the community overall in addition to the individual vaccinated person.	Difficulties with efforts to control measles in the 1960s and 1970s ushered in the modern era of immunization laws in the United States.12 In 1969, a total of 17 states had laws that required children to be vaccinated against measles before entering school, and 12 states had legally mandated requirements for vaccination against all six diseases for which routine immunization was carried out at the time.13 During the 1970s, efforts were made to strengthen and strictly enforce immunization laws.12,13 During measles outbreaks, some state and local health officials excluded from school those students who did not comply with immunization requirements, resulting in minimal backlash, quick improvement in local coverage, and control of outbreaks.19-22 Efforts by the public health community and other immunization advocates to increase measles vaccine coverage among school-age children resulted in enforcement of immunization requirements for all vaccines and the introduction of such requirements in states that did not already have them.	70_9

O	Increased enforcement of the laws often resulted in increased opposition to vaccination.	High immunization coverage has resulted in drastic declines in vaccine-preventable diseases, particularly in many high- and middle-income countries.	70_9

Massachusetts, which has since served as the foundation for public health laws, the U.S. Supreme Court endorsed the rights of states to pass and enforce compulsory vaccination laws.17 In 1922, deciding a case filed by a girl excluded from a public school (and later a private school) in San Antonio, Texas, the Supreme Court found school immunization requirements to be constitutional.18 Since then, courts have been generally supportive of the states' power to enact and implement immunization requirements.	70_9
O	Increased enforcement of the laws often resulted in increased opposition to vaccination.	Difficulties with efforts to control measles in the 1960s and 1970s ushered in the modern era of immunization laws in the United States.12 In 1969, a total of 17 states had laws that required children to be vaccinated against measles before entering school, and 12 states had legally mandated requirements for vaccination against all six diseases for which routine immunization was carried out at the time.13 During the 1970s, efforts were made to strengthen and strictly enforce immunization laws.12,13 During measles outbreaks, some state and local health officials excluded from school those students who did not comply with immunization requirements, resulting in minimal backlash, quick improvement in local coverage, and control of outbreaks.19-22 Efforts by the public health community and other immunization advocates to increase measles vaccine coverage among school-age children resulted in enforcement of immunization requirements for all vaccines and the introduction of such requirements in states that did not already have them.	70_9
O	Increased enforcement of the laws often resulted in increased opposition to vaccination.	By the beginning of the 1980s, all 50 states had school immunization requirements.	70_9
O	Increased enforcement of the laws often resulted in increased opposition to vaccination.	Recent School Immunization Requirements	70_9
O	Increased enforcement of the laws often resulted in increased opposition to vaccination.	Because laws concerning immunization are state-based, there are substantial differences in requirements across the country.	70_9
O	Increased enforcement of the laws often resulted in increased opposition to vaccination.	The requirements from state to state differ in terms of the school grades covered, the vaccines included, the processes and authority used to introduce new vaccines, reasons for exemptions (medical reasons, religious reasons, philosophical or personal beliefs), and the procedures for granting exemptions.23	70_9
O	Increased enforcement of the laws often resulted in increased opposition to vaccination.	State immunization laws contain provisions for certain exemptions.	70_9
O	Increased enforcement of the laws often resulted in increased opposition to vaccination.	As of March 2008, all states permitted medical exemptions from school immunization requirements, 48 states allowed religious exemptions, and 21 states allowed exemptions based on philosophical or personal beliefs.23 Several states (New York, Arkansas, and Texas) have recently expanded eligibility for exemptions.	70_9

O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	The factors known to be associated with exemption rates are heterogeneity in school policies28 and the beliefs of school personnel who are responsible for compliance with the immunization requirements.29	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	Instead of refusing vaccines, some parents delay vaccination of their children.30-32 Many parents follow novel vaccine schedules proposed by individual physicians (rather than those developed by expert committees with members representing multiple disciplines).32,33 Most novel schedules involve administering vaccines over a longer period than that recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices and the American Academy of Pediatrics or skipping the administration of some vaccines.	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	Individual Risk and Vaccine Refusal	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	Children with nonmedical exemptions are at increased risk for acquiring and transmitting vaccine-preventable diseases.34,35 In a retrospective cohort study based on nationwide surveillance data from 1985 through 1992, children with exemptions were 35 times as likely to contract measles as nonexempt children (relative risk, 35; 95% confidence interval [CI], 34 to 37).34 In a retrospective cohort study in Colorado based on data for the years 1987 through 1998, children with exemptions, as compared with unvaccinated children, were 22 times as likely to have had measles (relative risk, 22.2; 95% CI, 15.9 to 31.1) and almost six times as likely to have had pertussis (relative risk, 5.9; 95% CI, 4.2 to 8.2).35 Earlier data showed that lower incidences of measles and mumps were associated with the existence and enforcement of immunization requirements for school entry.12,36-38	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	The consequences of delayed vaccination, as compared with vaccine refusal, have not been studied in detail.	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	However, it is known that the risk of vaccine-preventable diseases and the risk of sequelae from vaccine-preventable diseases are not constant throughout childhood.	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	Young children are often at increased risk for illness and death related to infectious diseases, and vaccine delays may leave them vulnerable at ages with a high risk of contracting several vaccine-preventable diseases.	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	Moreover, novel vaccine schedules that recommend administering vaccines over a longer period may exacerbate health inequities, since parents with high socioeconomic status are more likely to make the extra visits required under the alternative schedules than parents with low socioeconomic status.39	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	Clustering of Vaccine Refusals and Community Risk	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	70_9
E	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	In Michigan, significant overlap between geographic clusters of nonmedical exemptions and pertussis clusters was documented.26 The odds ratio for the likelihood that a census tract included in a pertussis cluster would also be included in an exemptions cluster was 2.7 (95% CI, 2.5 to 3.6) after adjustment for demographic factors.	70_9
E	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	In Colorado, the county-level incidence of measles and pertussis in vaccinated children from 1987 through 1998 was associated with the frequency of exemptions in that county.35 At least 11% of the nonexempt children who acquired measles were infected through contact with an exempt child.35 Moreover, school-based outbreaks in Colorado have been associated with increased exemption rates; the mean exemption rate among schools with outbreaks was 4.3%, as compared with 1.5% for the schools that did not have an outbreak (P=0.001).35	70_9
E	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	High vaccine coverage, particularly at the community level, is extremely important for children who cannot be vaccinated, including children who have medical contraindications to vaccination and those who are too young to be vaccinated.	70_9
E	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	These groups are often more susceptible to the complications of infectious diseases than the general population of children and depend on the protection provided by the vaccination of children in their environs.40-42	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	Vaccine Refusal and the Recent Increase in Measles Cases	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	Measles vaccination has been extremely successful in controlling a disease that previously contributed to considerable morbidity and mortality.	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	In the United States, the reported number of cases dropped from an average of 500,000 annually in the era before vaccination (with reported cases considered to be a fraction of the estimated total, which was more than 2 million) to a mean of 62 cases per year from 2000 through 2007.43-45 Between January 1, 2008, and April 25, 2008, there were five measles outbreaks and a total of 64 cases reported.45 All but one of the persons with measles were either unvaccinated or did not have evidence of immunization.	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	Of the 21 cases among children and adolescents in the vaccine-eligible age group (16 months to 19 years) with a known reason for nonvaccination, 14, or 67%, had obtained a nonmedical exemption and all of the 10 school-age children had obtained a nonmedical exemption.45 Thirteen cases occurred in children too young to be vaccinated, and in more than a third of the cases (18 of 44) occurring in a known transmission setting the disease was acquired in a health care facility.45	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	Outbreaks of vaccine-preventable disease often start among persons who refused vaccination, spread rapidly within unvaccinated populations, and also spread to other subpopulations.	70_9
O	Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination.	For example, of the four outbreaks with discrete index cases (one outbreak occurred by means of multiple importations) reported January through April 2008, three out of four index cases occurred in people who had refused vaccination due to personal beliefs; vaccination status could not be verified for the remaining cases.45,46 In Washington State, a recent outbreak of measles occurred between April 12, 2008, and May 30, 2008, involving 19 cases.	70_9

Young children are often at increased risk for illness and death related to infectious diseases, and vaccine delays may leave them vulnerable at ages with a high risk of contracting several vaccine-preventable diseases.	70_9

O	Measles vaccination has been extremely successful in controlling a disease that previously contributed to considerable morbidity and mortality.	Who Refuses Vaccines and Why	70_9
O	Measles vaccination has been extremely successful in controlling a disease that previously contributed to considerable morbidity and mortality.	Using data from the National Immunization Survey for the period from 1995 through 2001, Smith et al.	70_9
O	Measles vaccination has been extremely successful in controlling a disease that previously contributed to considerable morbidity and mortality.	compared the characteristics of children between the ages of 19 and 35 months who did not receive any vaccine (unvaccinated) with the characteristics of those who were partially vaccinated (undervaccinated).47 As compared with the undervaccinated children, the unvaccinated children were more likely to be male, to be white, to belong to households with higher income, to have a married mother with a college education, and to live with four or more children.	70_9
O	Measles vaccination has been extremely successful in controlling a disease that previously contributed to considerable morbidity and mortality.	47 Other studies have shown that children who are unvaccinated are likely to belong to families that intentionally refuse vaccines, whereas children who are undervaccinated are likely to have missed some vaccinations because of factors related to the health care system or sociodemographic characteristics.48-51	70_9

O	Cicero's argument uses military episodes of plunder as case law and expresses certain standards when it comes to appropriating cultural property of another people [ref].	Napoleon's extensive plunder of Italy was criticized by such French artists as Antoine-Chrysostôme Quatremère de Quincy (1755–1849), who circulated a petition that gathered the signatures of fifty other artists [ref].	71_1
O	Cicero's argument uses military episodes of plunder as case law and expresses certain standards when it comes to appropriating cultural property of another people [ref].	With the founding of the Louvre Museum in Paris in 1793, Napoleon's aim was to establish an encyclopedic exhibition of art history, which later both Joseph Stalin and Adolf Hitler would attempt to emulate in their respective countries [ref].	71_1

Especially popular in Eastern Europe, some sites offer full access to messaging and profiles, but provide additional services for pay, such as bumping profiles up to the top of the list, removing advertisements, making paying users' profiles appear several times in different places in the search results, and giving paying users a more advanced search engine to work with (in one real example, free users may only search for persons of specified age, gender, orientation, and city, while subscribers may search for any and all parameters listed in profiles, such as height, weight, interests, etc.).	106_1

According to an online Monday, June 3, 2013, news story, by William Harms, of the University of Chicago (UChicagoNews) in Chicago, Illinois, a study by social neuroscience expert and National Advisory Council on Aging member Dr. John Cacioppo (Tiffany and Robert Blake Distinguished Service Professor of Psychology; Director, Center for Cognitive and Social Neuroscience, Social Psychology Doctoral Program, and the Social Neuroscience Laboratory) showed that more than a third of marriages between 2005 and 2012 began online, and that they tend to have happier, longer marriages than offline couples (meeting through work, school, church and places of worship, social gatherings, and less successfully, at bars or through offline blind dating).	106_1

O	According to an online Monday, June 3, 2013, news story, by William Harms, of the University of Chicago (UChicagoNews) in Chicago, Illinois, a study by social neuroscience expert and National Advisory Council on Aging member Dr. John Cacioppo (Tiffany and Robert Blake Distinguished Service Professor of Psychology; Director, Center for Cognitive and Social Neuroscience, Social Psychology Doctoral Program, and the Social Neuroscience Laboratory) showed that more than a third of marriages between 2005 and 2012 began online, and that they tend to have happier, longer marriages than offline couples (meeting through work, school, church and places of worship, social gatherings, and less successfully, at bars or through offline blind dating). O	According to an online Monday, June 3, 2013, news story, by William Harms, of the University of Chicago (UChicagoNews) in Chicago, Illinois, a study by social neuroscience expert and National Advisory Council on Aging member Dr. John Cacioppo (Tiffany and Robert Blake Distinguished Service Professor of Psychology; Director, Center for Cognitive and Social Neuroscience, Social Psychology Doctoral Program, and the Social Neuroscience Laboratory) showed that more than a third of marriages between 2005 and 2012 began online, and that they tend to have happier, longer marriages than offline couples (meeting through work, school, church and places of worship, social gatherings, and less successfully, at bars or through offline blind dating).	The results were published in the paper Marital Satisfaction and Breakups Differ Across Online and Offline Meeting Venues,” in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.	106_1
O	According to an online Monday, June 3, 2013, news story, by William Harms, of the University of Chicago (UChicagoNews) in Chicago, Illinois, a study by social neuroscience expert and National Advisory Council on Aging member Dr. John Cacioppo (Tiffany and Robert Blake Distinguished Service Professor of Psychology; Director, Center for Cognitive and Social Neuroscience, Social Psychology Doctoral Program, and the Social Neuroscience Laboratory) showed that more than a third of marriages between 2005 and 2012 began online, and that they tend to have happier, longer marriages than offline couples (meeting through work, school, church and places of worship, social gatherings, and less successfully, at bars or through offline blind dating).	Dr. Cacioppo led a team that examined the results of a representative sample of 19,131 people who responded to a survey by Harris Interactive about their marriages and satisfaction.	106_1
O	According to an online Monday, June 3, 2013, news story, by William Harms, of the University of Chicago (UChicagoNews) in Chicago, Illinois, a study by social neuroscience expert and National Advisory Council on Aging member Dr. John Cacioppo (Tiffany and Robert Blake Distinguished Service Professor of Psychology; Director, Center for Cognitive and Social Neuroscience, Social Psychology Doctoral Program, and the Social Neuroscience Laboratory) showed that more than a third of marriages between 2005 and 2012 began online, and that they tend to have happier, longer marriages than offline couples (meeting through work, school, church and places of worship, social gatherings, and less successfully, at bars or through offline blind dating).	People meeting online (45% did in the study) are more likely to be somewhat older (30-39), employed, and with a relatively higher income.	106_1

O	According to an online Monday, June 3, 2013, news story, by William Harms, of the University of Chicago (UChicagoNews) in Chicago, Illinois, a study by social neuroscience expert and National Advisory Council on Aging member Dr. John Cacioppo (Tiffany and Robert Blake Distinguished Service Professor of Psychology; Director, Center for Cognitive and Social Neuroscience, Social Psychology Doctoral Program, and the Social Neuroscience Laboratory) showed that more than a third of marriages between 2005 and 2012 began online, and that they tend to have happier, longer marriages than offline couples (meeting through work, school, church and places of worship, social gatherings, and less successfully, at bars or through offline blind dating). US government regulation of dating services began with the International Marriage Broker Regulation Act (IMBRA) which took effect in March 2007 after a federal judge in Georgia upheld a challenge from the dating site European Connections.	106_1

O	According to an online Monday, June 3, 2013, news story, by William Harms, of the University of Chicago (UChicagoNews) in Chicago, Illinois, a study by social neuroscience expert and National Advisory Council on Aging member Dr. John Cacioppo (Tiffany and Robert Blake Distinguished Service Professor of Psychology; Director, Center for Cognitive and Social Neuroscience, Social Psychology Doctoral Program, and the Social Neuroscience Laboratory) showed that more than a third of marriages between 2005 and 2012 began online, and that they tend to have happier, longer marriages than offline couples (meeting through work, school, church and places of worship, social gatherings, and less successfully, at bars or through offline blind dating).	Singapore's government has actively acted as a matchmaker for singles for the past few decades, and thus only 4 percent of Singaporeans have ever used an online dating service, despite the country’s high rate of internet penetration.	106_1

O	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	In 1989 the University of Phoenix began offering education programs through the internet.	108_3
O	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	In 1993 with the debut of the first Internet web browser, created by the University of Illinois, online learning began to flourish [ref].	108_3
O	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	In 1998, the first fully online programs were founded: New York University Online, Western Governor's University, the California Virtual University[3] and Trident University International [ref].	108_3
O	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	In 2000 only 8% of students were enrolled in an online course, but by 2008 enrollment had increased to 20% [ref].	108_3
O	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	The expansion of online education has not slowed either; by the fall of 2013 nearly 30% of all postsecondary students were enrolled in some kind of distance education course [ref].	108_3
O	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	Although the data on online course and program completion are complex [ref], researchers have noted high rates of attrition (ranging from 20%-50%) among students enrolled in online courses compared to those who take traditional face-to-face courses [ref].	108_3
O	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	Types of learner experiences (methods of delivery)[edit]	108_3

Online platforms can also offer more diverse representations of student populations as learners prepare for working in the twenty-first century [ref].	108_3
E	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	The diversity comes from interacting with students outside of one's geographical location, possibly offering a variety of perspectives on course content [ref].	108_3
E	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	Courses offered completely online are primarily delivered in an asynchronous learning or synchronous learning format.	108_3
E	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	Asynchronous learning environments are described as online spaces where work is supported through the use of digital platforms in such a way that participants are not required to be online at the same time [ref].	108_3
E	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	Threaded discussions, e-mail, and telephone calls are options of asynchronous delivery [ref].	108_3
E	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	This gives meaning to the anytime-anywhere appeal of online learning.	108_3
E	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	A benefit of asynchronous learning is the learner having more time to generate content-related responses to the instructor and peer postings; they have time to find facts to back their written statements [ref].	108_3
E	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	The additional time provides an opportunity to increase the learner's ability to process information [ref].	108_3
E	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	The spelling and grammar within postings of an asynchronous environment are like that found in formal academic writing [ref].	108_3
O	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	On the other hand, one of the main limitations of this delivery method is the greater potential for a learner to feel removed from the learning environment.	108_3
O	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	Asynchronous learning is viewed as less social in nature and can cause the learner to feel isolated [ref].	108_3
O	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	Providing the student a feeling of belonging to the university or institution will assist with feelings of isolation; this can be done through ensuring links to university support systems and the library are accessible and operable [ref].	108_3
E	Given the improvements in delivery methods, online learning environments provide a greater degree of flexibility than traditional classroom settings [ref].	Synchronous learning environments most closely resemble face-to-face learning [ref].	108_3

Pedagogy[edit]	108_3
O	There are four fundamental characteristics that may assist with the success of online instruction: (1) the learner should be actively engaged throughout the course; (2) group participation can assist with meeting course objectives; (3) frequent student-student and student-teacher interaction can alleviate the feelings of isolation; and (4) the course content should relate to the real world to enhance meaning for participants [ref]..	Transformative learning or Transformative pedagogy encourages students to critically examine their assumptions, grapple with social issues, and engage in social action ( p. 219[25]).	108_3
E	There are four fundamental characteristics that may assist with the success of online instruction: (1) the learner should be actively engaged throughout the course; (2) group participation can assist with meeting course objectives; (3) frequent student-student and student-teacher interaction can alleviate the feelings of isolation; and (4) the course content should relate to the real world to enhance meaning for participants [ref]..	Five suggestions for preparing the online environment for transformative pedagogy are: (a) create a safe and inviting environment; (b) encourage students to think about their experiences, beliefs, and biases; (c) use teaching strategies that promote student engagement and participation; (d) pose real-world problems that address societal inequalities; and (e) help students implement action-oriented solutions (p. 220[25]).	108_3

O	Expectations of learners to be self-motivated, able to manage their time effectively, contribute to course discussions and have a willingness to teach others is not unlike what is expected in a traditional classroom.	Five suggestions for preparing the online environment for transformative pedagogy are: (a) create a safe and inviting environment; (b) encourage students to think about their experiences, beliefs, and biases; (c) use teaching strategies that promote student engagement and participation; (d) pose real-world problems that address societal inequalities; and (e) help students implement action-oriented solutions (p. 220[25]).	108_3

O	Online purchases can take taxes away from the local economy.	As a result, residents of a state may not pay sales taxes on online purchases that they would have paid if they had made the same purchase in a brick and mortar store.	109_9
